prompt.p: A 26-year-old type 1 diabetic is admitted following a 48-h history of diarrhoea and vomiting. During this time she has missed her insulin doses.
On examination she is pyrexial at 38.5°C, drowsy with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of E3 M5 V4 and tachypnoeic. Clinically she appears to be dehydrated with a blood pressure of 80/65 mmHg.
What is the initial treatment priority?

modalFeedback.p: Option A (0.9% saline IV) is Correct. This is the fluid replacement of choice in this situation.
Option B 1.4% sodium bicarbonate) is Incorrect. This may be used in severe diabetic ketoacidosis guided by blood gas therapy but should only be instituted following review by a senior clinician.

Option C (5% dextrose IV) is Incorrect. The likely diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis – she requires fluid replacement initially with 0.9% saline, followed by 5% dextrose once normoglycaemia is achieved.
Option D (Actrapid 10 U SC) is Incorrect. Insulin is required but the initial step should be to begin restoration of the circulating volume.
Option E (Co-amoxiclav 1.2g IV) is Incorrect. While antibiotic therapy may be required, this is not an immediate treatment priority.
